008 *******************************************************************************/
009package imagingbook.common.filter.generic;
010
011import imagingbook.common.image.PixelPack;
012
013/**
014 * <p>
015 * This (abstract) class represents a filter which treats all pixel data 
016 * as vectors.
017 * The filter calls the method {@link #doPixel(PixelPack, int, int)}
018 * for each image pixel, which must be implemented by any concrete
019 * sub-class.
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * Thus a custom filter based on this class only needs to specify the steps
023 * to be performed for a single pixel. The remaining filter mechanics
024 * including multiple components, out-of-bounds coordinate handling,
025 * multiple passes and data copying are handled by this class and its super-class
026 * (see {@link GenericFilter}).
027 * </p>
028 */
029public abstract class GenericFilterVector extends GenericFilter {
030
031        private int iter = 0;
032        private int iterMax = 1;        // for progress reporting only
033        
034        @Override 
035        protected void runPass(PixelPack sourcePack, PixelPack targetPack) {
036                final int width = sourcePack.getWidth();
037                final int height = sourcePack.getHeight();
038                iterMax = width * height;
039                iter = 0;
040                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
041                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
042                                targetPack.setPix(u, v, doPixel(sourcePack, u, v)); // single pixel operation
043                                iter++;
044                        }
045                }
046                iter = 0;
047        }
048        
049        /**
050         * This method defines the steps to be performed for a single image pixel and
051         * must be implemented by any concrete sub-class.
052         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelPack} container, which
053         * holds the pixel values of all image components.
054         * The method {@link PixelPack#getPix(int, int)} should be used to read
055         * individual pixel vectors. These data should not be modified but
056         * the (float[]) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
057         * Implementations are free to return the same float-array at each invocation,
058         * i.e., there is no need to allocate a new array every time.
059         * 
060         * @param source the vector-valued image data
061         * @param u the current x-position
062         * @param v the current y-position
063         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
064         */
065        protected abstract float[] doPixel(PixelPack source, int u, int v);
066        
067        // -----------------------------------------------------------------
068        
069        @Override
070        protected final double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
071                double localProgress = (double) iter /iterMax;
072                //System.out.println("GenericFilterVector: reportProgress() - returning " + localProgress);
073                return super.reportProgress(localProgress);
074        }
075
076}
